fields.description:
h3. Summary
Git Large File Storage (or LFS) is a new, open-source extension to Git that aims to improve handling of large files. Source code checkouts fail in Bamboo when linked to LFS-enabled repositories

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a repository with [Git LFS enabled|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Git+Large+File+Storage#GitLargeFileStorage-repolfsEnablingGitLFSforarepository]
# Add file types for LFS to manage and include at least one file of that type in the repository
# [Install git-lfs client extension|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Git+Large+File+Storage#GitLargeFileStorage-InstallingtheGitLFScommandlineclient] on Bamboo server
# Link LFS-enabeld repository to build plan with a [source checkout task|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/checking-out-code-289277060.html] enabled

h3. Expected Results
Source checkout should complete successfully

h3. Actual Results
When Bamboo attempts to checkout repositories with git-lfs enabled, the checkout process fails with "Error accessing media" and "smudge filter lfs failed" errors. The following stack trace can be found in *<BAMBOO_INST>/logs/catalina.out*{noformat}2016-01-28 05:04:00,499 ERROR [13-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-28-thread-1] [TaskExecutorImpl] Error occurred while running Task 'Checkout Default Repository(1)' of type com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.vcs:task.vcs.checkout.
java.lang.RuntimeException: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: MAV-MBT-JOB1-201: Checkout to revision 6681d2b8c3009b04ab49b949d31832cd03939ad6 has failed.command /usr/bin/git checkout -f master failed with code 128. Working directory was [/var/atlassian/application-data/bamboo_510/xml-data/build-dir/131073/MAV-MBT-JOB1]., stderr:
Downloading test3.jpg (12.57 MB)
Error accessing media: test3.jpg (24fda5852ed8527b134501db6877591edbefbadb6f4e05ba5c8c4c4c91f73f92)

Errors logged to .git/lfs/objects/logs/20160128T050400.487728317.log
Use `git lfs logs last` to view the log.
error: external filter git-lfs smudge %f failed 2

fatal: test3.jpg: smudge filter lfs failed

error: external filter git-lfs smudge %f failed
fatal: test3.jpg: smudge filter lfs failed
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.runCommand(GitCommandProcessor.java:587)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.runCommand(GitCommandProcessor.java:530)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.runCheckoutCommandForBranchOrRevision(GitCommandProcessor.java:337)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandProcessor.runCheckoutCommand(GitCommandProcessor.java:331)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.NativeGitOperationHelper.checkout(NativeGitOperationHelper.java:352)
	... 29 more{noformat}

h3.Workaround
In order to checkout git-lfs enabled repositories, the checkout must be performed manually via a scripted task. For example, the following script will perform a checkout for the current branch of your configured plan and can be used in place of the source code checkout task (please note this is a very basic example and your needs may require more customisation):
{code}git init
git remote add -t ${bamboo.planRepository.branchName} -f origin https://username:password@mygitrepo.org/scm/proj/myrepo.git
git checkout -f ${bamboo.planRepository.branchName}
{code}
fields.summary: Add support for Git LFS

fields.description:
Guys,

The current [Dragons Stage 8 - Install Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ATLAS/Dragons+Stage+8+-+Install+Bamboo#DragonsStage8-InstallBamboo-Step3.SetUpBamboo] has some inconsistencies.

In *Step 2. Install Bamboo* we are asked to download&install Bamboo 5.3. This version has already reached [End Of Life|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/Support/Atlassian+Support+End+of+Life+Policy] and doesn't support Java 8.

In *Step 3. Set Up Bamboo* we are asked to download&install the latest Atlassian Plugin SDK that relies on Java 8.

Can you please update *Step 2. Install Bamboo* to point to the latest version of Bamboo available (5.10.0)? Just please bear in mind that the latest version relies on Java 8 and doesn't work with Java 7. So down the road we will *not* be able to add a JDK 1.7 server capability, as the documentation assumes we installed Java 7 in Dragons Stage 1. We will have to either update Stage 1 to point the user to download&install Java 8 or add an additional step to Stage 8 to install Java 8 before installing Bamboo 5.10.0.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Documentation - Dragons Stage 8 - Install Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bamboo has two export methods:
* while running Scheduled Backup (under {color:blue}Bamboo administration >> System >> Scheduled backups{color})
* while running Export (under {color:blue}Bamboo administration >> System >> Export{color})

h3. Issue
An export can fail because of (_a few examples_):
* OOM (_OutOfMemory_)
* inconsistent data 

h3. Suggestion
The incomplete export zip should then be deleted as it's useless, and can leave a false impression that a backup/export was created successfully
fields.summary: Delete incomplete zip when export fails
REST endpoint for latest Job result doesn't provide complete list of artifacts

We are trialing bamboo on the cloud with a remote agent and came across the problem as in ticket BAM-17124.  Could we please have the workaround applied to our installation?

https://grappler.atlassian.net/builds/agentServer/ - this is the base url I noticed while installing the remote agent

An early response on this would be highly appreciated as we are blocked on this.
fields.summary: Artifacts are not published from Remote Agent

fields.description:
If I have two or more manual stages and let's say select the 2nd one to be run, then the 1st is auto selected (unwanted) but even more than that, this is getting ready only and cannot be deselected.

Searching the Web for a workaround ("skip manual stages in Bamboo") I found that it has been   complained about that quite frequently.

We, a Team at Citrix Systems Inc., have this issue independently from deployment (where another ticket in this Jira points to as resolved). 

Our user story: 
As developers using Bamboo for CI, 
we would like to have the option to selectively run (manual) stages without the need to run every manual stage prior to which was selected, 
so that a developer who manually triggered stages selectively, is getting early result(s) just of that single / selected stage(s) he is interested in.
fields.summary: Ability to skip manual stage(s)

fields.summary: Running a build from plan page throws internal server error

fields.description:
h3. Replicate issue
# create a "{{Project / Plan}}"
# create a "{{Deployment / Environment}}" to consume the plan above created
# add a "{{Script}}" task to the Deployment:
{code}
echo "adding task to sleep deployment"
sleep 600
{code}
# add "{{After successful build plan}}" as "{{Trigger}}"
# run build Plan

Once the plan builds successfully, the Deployment will be triggered and you should see the following entry in Bamboo logs
{code:title=<bamboo-install>/logs/catalina.out}
2016-01-26 13:44:27,323 INFO [13-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-28-thread-1] [ProcessServiceImpl] Beginning to execute external process for build 'Deployment of 'release-1' on 'Environment'....
{code}

At this moment, you can pause Bamboo:
h4. Pausing Bamboo
{code}
curl -u BAMBOO_ADMIN_USER:BAMBOO_ADMIN_PASSWORD -X POST http:/localhost:8085/bamboo/rest/api/latest/server/pause
{code}
When running the command above, the following can be found in Bamboo logs
{code:title=<bamboo-install>/logs/catalina.out}
2016-01-26 13:44:34,719 INFO [http-nio-8085-exec-2] [ServerLifecycleManagerImpl] Server state changed to 'PAUSING' from 'RUNNING' by 'BAMBOO_ADMIN_USER'
2016-01-26 13:44:34,721 INFO [5-Server Lifecycle Manager:pool-11-thread-1] [ServerLifecycleManagerImpl] Server state changed to 'PAUSED' from 'PAUSING'
{code}

h3. Actual Results
If you go to "{{Build activity}}" in Bamboo, you will notice the Deployment continues on being displayed as building even though Bamboo has already changed its state to 'PAUSE''

h3. Expected Results
Wait deployment to finish before change state to 'PAUSE'

h3. Notes
Since Bamboo is not taking into consideration Deployments before changing state, it will be required to Stop the Deployment under "{{Build activity}}", for instance, so Bamboo can continue on running builds/deployments when Bamboo gets resumed.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

* User was looking for a way to exclude scheduled instances from automatic elastic instance management*

In Atlassian Cloud it is not possible to have Bamboo automatically spin up new agents at certain threshold and have them shielded from tear down due to a scheduled elastic instances event to *Stop all elastic instances*. 

It is possible to schedule an elastic instances with a Cron expressions to start and tear shut down all elastic instance at a determined time (typically end of day). Schedule can be configured here: <EXAMPLE>.atlassian.net/builds/admin/elastic/schedule/viewElasticInstanceSchedules.action. However, the tear down scheduled will shut down down any newly created elastic instance (for volume) and the scheduled elastic instances. There is no way of separating which elastic instances should shut down and which to keep until until a scheduled stop.

h3. Suggested Solution

User would like a way to be able to configure the schedule setting to allow more flexibility for elastic instances. Either a way to configure elastic instance independently or pass parameters to stop only certain type of scheduled instance. 
 
h3. Workaround 

None at this time
fields.summary: Provide Bamboo Cloud instances additional options for scheduling elastic instances on schedules

The error message "{{Mail server ..... is not of required type *javax.mail.Session*, .... It is of type '*javax.mail.Session*' .... instead}}" is basically saying that 1 != 1.

*NOTE:* The exact same setup works in Bamboo 5.9.7.

h2. Workaround:
# Shutdown Bamboo
# Remove {{mail-X.X.jar}} and {{activation-X.X.jar}} from {{<Bamboo-Install>/lib}}
# *Move* (do not just copy) {{<Bamboo-Install>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/lib/javax.mail-1.5.2.jar}} into {{<Bamboo-Install>/lib}}
# Start Bamboo

fields.description:
The following documentation pages have outdated IP ranges as they recently changed:
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/pull-request-post-service-management-385913080.html
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/manage-webhooks-735643732.html (Triggering webhooks section)

Correct ones can be found at: https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/what-are-the-bitbucket-ip-addresses-i-should-use-to-configure-my-corporate-firewall-343343385.html
And that documentation could use an update to put the Current ones one top. :)

Outbound IPs for hooks: 104.192.143.192/28 & 104.192.143.208/28

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When accessing Bamboo over an HTTPS connector configured in Tomcat's server.xml, the UI appears broken under certain browsers as some CSS/JS resources are not being loaded.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure an HTTPS connector in <BAMBOO_INST>/conf/server.xml
# Start Bamboo and attempt to connect over HTTPS in Chrome or Firefox

Note: This issue does _not_ present in Safari.


h3. Expected Results
UI should load as normal

h3. Actual Results
* UI appears broken, as the browser refuses to load certain CSS/jQuery resources. See attached *bamboo_login_ui.png*
* Chrome throws an ERR_SSL_PROTOCOL_ERROR. See attached *bamboo_510_https_connector.har*

h3.Workaround
The HTTPS connector definition in *<BAMBOO_INST>/conf/server.xml* can be modified to work around this. Add the following attribute:

{noformat}
protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11Protocol"
{noformat}
to your existing HTTPS connector declaration.
fields.summary: CSS/JS resources not loaded over Tomcat HTTPS connector, breaking UI

fields.description:
Bamboo should provide a way to lockout accounts after multiple failed logins.

A proposed solution would be to have a settings in Bamboo defining the maximum number of allowed login attempts and to lockout accounts after too many failed attempts.
fields.summary: Bamboo should lockout accounts after multiple failed login attempts

fields.description: Bamboo does not require users to configure a different password than the previous one they entered. As a result users can keep on re-using the same password over and over.
fields.summary: Bamboo should require a user to use a new password when changing it

fields.description:
It is possible to test if an account exists in Bamboo by using the password reset feature as we display different messages for valid and invalid accounts.

A solution for this would be to have a similar confirmation message upon submission.
fields.summary: Password reset feature should not allow enumeration of account

fields.description:
It looks like Bamboo creates a bat file called devenvrunner.bat and uses this to run build commands.

The problem is that it contains 2 lines:

call "%BAM_VS_HOME%\VC\vcvarsall.bat" %BAM_VS_ARCH%
call "%BAM_VS_HOME%\Common7\IDE\devenv.com" %BAM_ARGS%

The problem with the first line is that vcvarsall.bat does not exist in VS 2015

The problem with the second line is that when the build happens, this expands to:

c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\Common7\Common7\IDE\devenv.com

instead of

c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\Common7\\IDE\devenv.com


Here are the errors:

21-Jan-2016 14:28:27	c:\bamboo\build-dir\CXN-CXN13-JOB1>call "c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\Common7\VC\vcvarsall.bat" x86 
21-Jan-2016 14:28:27	The system cannot find the path specified.
21-Jan-2016 14:28:27	
21-Jan-2016 14:28:27	c:\bamboo\build-dir\CXN-CXN13-JOB1>call "c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\Common7\Common7\IDE\devenv.com"  "Connexion.sln" /clean debug 

Version: Continuous integration powered by Atlassian Bamboo version 5.10.0 build 51017 - 15 Jan 16
fields.summary: Cannot build project with Visual Studio 2015
Better handling of running script in subdirectory that does not exist

fields.description:
Let's start from a real world example: Tomcat deploy/undeploy tasks.

h2. Currently...
I have a _template_ build plan, which is to be cloned into new build plans for other projects. One of the tasks is to undeploy/redeploy a WAR file into preconfigured SIT.
The first time I launch the build it will never succeed because the application has never been deployed. It will actually never deploy for the first time because subsequent builds will attempt to undeploy an application not deployed.
I have to manually deploy the app for the first time and then Bamboo can enter the loop of intragration that is really "continuous". Or to disable the undeploy task just for the first time...
Little annoying.

h2. Desiderata
When I create a build task I would like to mark it as "non-blocking", or "optional" with a checkbox, so that its failure will be only logged but won't affect the possibility to run the rest of the build plan

h2. Alternate desiderata
To implement a whole new category of taks. Remember the rule between normal job tasks and "final" job tasks? Ok, since tasks that perform environment preparation or pre-cleaning could be all considered such "optional", why not adding a category of tasks above the standard job tasks?

Example: when I create a task it's assigned to the normal task queue. If I drag to the bottom of the list it will be final as now. If I drag the task to the top, above a new separator to be implemented in UI, a message will tell "Preparation tasks: the build will run even if they fail"



What do you think about this?
fields.summary: Consider a task "optional" in terms of failure

fields.description:
Yesterday I have performed Bamboo upgrade from 5.9.7 to 5.10.0. As of the upgrade guide, I did not perform any action on my single remote agent as it would have upgraded automatically.

After kickstarting Bamboo again on my master node, I saw a Tomcat-related job failing. Please not that I did *not* make modifications to the plan and it runs fine on any *local agent*

Explanation of build plan:
1. Compile the web application into a war and publish the artifact (together with other artifacts)
2. Get the war from the previous stage and deploy in SIT
3. Manually push other published artifacts to Artifactory (not involved in this bug report)

In order to evaluate and learn remote agents in Bamboo, I have dedicated the SIT remote agent to do step 2 of the job.

Following is a summary of the failing build plan:
 - Job 1 is successful and I can manually download artifacts. Their file names are correct. I have attached the last lines of the log to the ticket
 - Job 2 fails and logs to be unable to download the artifacts (log file 244)

Then running that same job on local agent succeeds (as for log 245).  Please *note* that build 245 was run at midnight on remote agent, then re-run on local agent at 8AM. I have seen the log 245 show lines from both builds.

Since I did no modification to my plan I don't think there is any issue with it. I also tried to reinstall remote agent from scratch and it did came back to normal work again.
Now that I have written all this report I prefer to submit to Atlassian for investigating possible problems with auto-upgrade, but I have workarounded my issue.
fields.summary: Bamboo remote agent won't download artifacts after upgrade to 5.10.0 of master

fields.description:
*Problem*

When overriding an obscured password field, (Run Customised -> Override a variable) while the initial password is hidden, any subsequent edits will not be. 

As such, it could be possible to clear the field and potentially have the password exposed while editing. However, once saved, will be correctly obscured in the UI and logs.

*Improvement* 

Treat the field in the same way that other password fields are in Bamboo and have all characters hidden when being edited.
fields.summary: When overriding a password variable, new edits are displayed

fields.description:
Bamboo has a slick interface, but there needs to be a way to export a plan configuration to a file so that it can be checked into a repo and changes monitored.

If we can export, then we should be able to import as well.
fields.summary: import/export JSON config files

fields.description:
It would be great if I could add checkboxes to a "Run customised build" dialog.
If I check it, for example, the variable will be set to "true", otherwise it is left as "false".

I could use a custom variable for that, but this would be not intuitive and explicit for users. 
There are many variables in my project including user-defined and service variables (not needed for users).
In that way the list of available variables becomes confusing for everyone because It combines more and less important variables just in one place.
Eventually I have to explain which variables are editable and what they are meant for and good naming doesn't help much.

So I want users to understand what they *can* and *should* customise by looking at the "Run customised build" dialog.

Under the hood those checkboxes could be made just as same build variables with a corresponding true or false value.
fields.summary: Ability to add checkboxes to a "Run customised build" dialog

fields.description:
There are a number of places in the log where this occurs including the start and ending task messages. In this case the task description is *CLI integration automation*. Other places in the log also have the text *automation* masked. Now it just so happens *automation* is a password. What is going on?

{noformat}
19-Jan-2016 12:09:52	Starting task 'CLI integration ********' of type
19-Jan-2016 12:09:52	Finished task 'CLI integration ********' with result: Success
{noformat}

This did not happen on any previous Bamboo release including 5.9.x.

By the way, this actually *exposes the password* to anyone who can see the log and determine the text that is being masked. Not that important in this case, but, don't know what the logic is that is doing the masking.
fields.summary: Regular text is being masked in the log
REST endpoint for latest Chain result doesn't provide list of artifacts

fields.description:
I have a project that builds from multiple repos. Often developers will make changes in more than one repo. I need a way to wait for all pull requests have be merged before running a build. Otherwise we see a lot of failed builds until the developer merges the final pull request.

I tried the repo "quiet period" but this didn't work as expected for multiple repos. A commit from repo "A" begins the quiet period but the commits from repos "B" & "C" were NOT included in the build during the quiet period. And I have to run the build manually to include repo "B" & "C" changes.

Thanks,

 - Neil
fields.summary: Trigger that waits for all pull requests to be merged from multiple stash repos

fields.description:
For development teams that use the pull request model, many times a branch will have only one push and hence only one Bamboo build.  Currently the "Commits" tab for the first build on a branch is empty.  This makes sense from the perspective that there weren't any commits since the previous build on the branch, but isn't very useful to the developer.

When I submit a pull request and that pull request is built by Bamboo, I would like for the commits in the pull request to show up in the commits tab in Bamboo.

I realize it's not well defined from Bamboo's perspective which commits should be included, since Bamboo doesn't know about the pull request, only about the branch, and I don't think there's any way to know which parent branch the child branch was branched off from.  So I won't propose exactly how to implement it.

Here are some ideas, however:

- At the very least, the text for the Code commits tab should explain why there are no code changes: because it's the first build on the branch.
- Better though would be tighter integration with BitBucket pull requests.  BitBucket knows which commits comprise the pull request because the developer specified the parent branch when they created the pull request.
- Maybe instead of a plan based on branches, Bamboo could have a "build pull requests" feature?

Here is an example to illustrate:

- [pull request commits tab|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian-marketplace/shim/pull-requests/4/amkt-14297-metrics-for-http-requests-sent/commits] shows one commit
- Clicking through to the build for that commit, we see [this build|https://ecosystem-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/browse/AMKT-SHIM3-BUILD-1/commit] which shows "No code changes" because it's the only build on that branch.
fields.summary: Show the commit history for first build of a PR branch

h4. Duplication Steps
# Go to *cog icon > Linked Repositories*
# Select repository type of *Bitbucket*
# Enter in username and password, select Load Repositories
(i) 401 error received. 
# Select the password field and press *Enter*
(i) "Please select a repository." is displayed under Load Repositories
# Select Load Repositories, and repository will become available.
fields.summary: Bitbucket repository configuration, enter must be pressed or 401 error received

fields.description:
Add a note that in order for testcases to display in Bamboo the *classname* and *name* elements must be used in the junit-results.xml regardless if testcase passed or failed. 

Documentation: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/JUnit+Parser
fields.summary: Bamboo Documentation: Junit Parser notation needed

fields.description:
When I launch a build on AIX agent, I have the following error in agent's logs:
{code}
CannotResolveClassException: java.lang.ref.ReferenceQueue$Null
{code}

The build itself fails with following error message:
{code}
Build XXX-JOB1-3 had to be cancelled: it was marked as queued but was not present in the queue for (at least) the past 720 seconds.

fields.description: Currently the Support Zip has to be retrieved manually and this can be a hassle for some users without server access but with admin access to Bamboo. We should make the zip available to download from the UI.
fields.summary: Make the Support Zip downloadable from the UI

fields.description:
Currently a Bamboo build cannot access the metadata contained within the push payload of a commit that triggers a Bamboo build. This data contains everything from author and timestamp to revision number as well as other things that may want to be consumed/action upon in the process of a Bamboo build.

Customer Comment:
{quote}
There are multiple reasons we need to process the push-payload....

* Identify when a commit was pushed to a particular branch (in our case
'release') on any one of our repositories
* Identify when a commit was pushed without a valid JIRA issue ID
mentioned in the commit message
* Update the associated JIRA issues (after scraping the JIRA id from the
commit message) with the branch it was pushed to
{quote}

In general features like this can improve release management within Bamboo when it's not linked to an external system that manages releases (such as JIRA).
fields.summary: Make triggering commit push-payload data available to Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Using "Block build if parent plans have unbuilt changes" blocking strategy will produce two child builds if parent has unbuilt changes and Concurrent builds are enabled

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set Plan A to be the parent of Plan B
# Remove Plan A trigger
# Set Plan B trigger to be "Repository polling" (10 seconds)
# Set "Block build if parent plans have unbuilt changes" blocking strategy in Plan B
# Set Concurrent builds to be more than 2
# Push a commit to Plan A
# Push a commit to Plan B

h3. Expected Results
Plan A will be triggered. After Plan A finish building, Plan B will be triggered once

h3. Actual Results
Plan A will be triggered. After Plan A finish building, Plan B is triggered twice (one from Repository polling and the other from Parent Plan A)
fields.summary: "Block build if parent plans have unbuilt changes" blocking strategy will produce two builds in child plan

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Only "Repository polling" trigger will trigger the parent plan if it has unbuilt changes

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set Plan A to be the parent of Plan B
# Remove Plan A trigger
# Set Plan B trigger to be "Single daily build" that will be triggered in 10 minutes
# Set "Block build if parent plans have unbuilt changes" blocking strategy in Plan B
# Push a commit to Plan A
# Push a commit to Plan B

h3. Expected Results
Plan A will be triggered. After Plan A finish building, Plan B will be triggered

h3. Actual Results
Only Plan B is triggered
 
h3. Notes
"Single daily build" trigger and "Manual run" tested not working
"Repository polling" trigger tested working fine (Plan A is triggered)
fields.summary: "Block build if parent plans have unbuilt changes" blocking strategy only works with "Repository polling" trigger

fields.description:
An artifact name can be arbitrary characters. If the artifact name includes a plus symbol {{+}}, for example, that will be interpreted as a space when the URL is looked up.

It makes downloading some artifacts impossible unless you manually enter the correct URL encoded parameter in the address bar yourself.

fields.description:
*Bamboo* exposed services without first performing authentication checks. Attackers can use this vulnerability to extract confidential information from *Bamboo*, modify certain settings and manage build agents. To exploit this issue, attackers need to be able to access the *Bamboo* JMS port.

*Affected versions:*
* All versions of Bamboo from 2.4 before 5.9.9 (the fixed version for 5.9.x) are affected by this vulnerability.

\\
*Fix:*
* Bamboo 5.10.0 is available for download from https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download.
* Bamboo 5.9.9 is available for download from https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download-archives.

\\
For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/VzlZLw].
fields.summary: CVE-2015-8361: Services exposed without authentication Vulnerability

fields.description:
*Bamboo* had a resource that deserialised arbitrary user input without restriction. Attackers can use this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that have a vulnerable version of *Bamboo*. To exploit this issue, attackers need to be able to access the *Bamboo* JMS port (port 54663 by default).

*Affected versions:*
* All versions of Bamboo from 2.3.1 before 5.9.9 (the fixed version for 5.9.x) are affected by this vulnerability.

\\
*Fix:*
* Bamboo 5.10.0 is available for download from https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download.
* Bamboo 5.9.9 is available for download from https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download-archives.

\\
For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/VzlZLw].
fields.summary: CVE-2015-8360: Deserialisation Resulting in Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

fields.description:
Documentation at https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/viewing-a-build-s-artifacts-289276930.html mentions a way of retrieving artifacts that are locally in Bamboo.

With the new S3 artifacts storage functionality, artifacts are not found on the URL mentioned on the guide.

Instead, they are found at https://<BAMBOO-URL>/builds/build/result/artifactUrlRedirect.action?planKey=<PLAN-KEY>&artifactName=<ARTIFACT-NAME>

To download with CURL, the Location parameter -L is needed because there is a redirect to S3.
Example:
{noformat}
curl -L -u user:password -X GET "https://<BAMBOO-URL>/builds/build/result/artifactUrlRedirect.action?planKey=<PLAN-KEY>&artifactName=<ARTIFACT-NAME>" > myArtifact.zip
{noformat}

Documentation requires an update to include the new storage option.
fields.summary: Artifacts documentation requires update for S3

fields.description:
*Bamboo* used an old version of the Smack XMPP library that deserialises messages received from XMPP. Attackers can use this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that have a vulnerable version of *Bamboo* if a XMPP connection has been configured. To exploit this issue, *Bamboo* attackers need to be able to modify XMPP messages destined to *Bamboo* from a configured XMPP server.

*Affected versions:*
* All versions of *Bamboo* from 2.4 before 5.9.9 (the fixed version for 5.9.x) are affected by this vulnerability. 

\\
*Fix:*
* Bamboo 5.10.0 is available for download from https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download.
* Bamboo 5.9.9 is available for download from https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download-archives.

\\
For additional details see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/VzlZLw].
fields.summary: CVE-2014-9757: Deserialisation Through Smack Resulting in Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

It would be nice if there was an option for the specific filepath (including Dockerfile name). This would allow further customization of that Dockerfile.
fields.summary: Docker task does not allow for custom named Dockerfile

fields.description:
I am developing a plugin that needs to extract all the changed files from an SVN repository related to a JIRA Version (release). Note that I'm looking for the CHANGED files only.
I was using the BuildRepositoryChanges class to figure out what was changed for a certain JIRA version. However, the content of buildContext.getBuildChanges().getRepositoryChanges() does not represent all commits for all the JIRA issues in a release (FixVersion). It just looks at the revision number since the last build and only has the changes since the last build.

In other words, the BuildRepositoryChanges ignores the JIRA fixVersion/ Release related JIRAs and commits and just contains the changes since the last build just like any other build.

I think the BuildRepositoryChanges should represent the JIRA issues and commits related to the fixVersion / JIRA Relase.

Example scenario:
commit 1 - JIRA issue #1 - fixVersion #1
commit 2 - JIRA issue #2 - fixVersion #2
commit 3 - JIRA issue #3 - fixVersion #1
When I release fixVersion #1, I need commit 1 and 3, and JIRA issue #1 and #3
When I release fixVersion #2, i need commit 2 and JIRA issue #2

To make matters worse, I can't do it myself in a plugin because of the issue described in BAM-17061.
fields.summary: BuildRepositoryChanges not accurate for JIRA Release

fields.description:
h3. Summary
"All logged in users" can be set to Admin Global Permission

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Navigate to {{Administration >> Security >> Global Permissions}}
# Edit Global Permission
# Remove all the "Admin" permission for Users and Groups
# Select the option "Admin" for "All logged in users"
# Save the setting

h3. Expected Results
The option to select "Admin" for "All logged in users" shouldn't exist

h3. Actual Results
"All logged in users" can be set to Admin Global Permission even though the Saved Global Permission page isn't showing it
fields.summary: "All logged in users" can be set to Admin Global Permission

fields.description:
detailed question here
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/33148493/answers/33148599?flashId=1093353246
1. Create a local install of Bamboo Server. 
2. Change the IP address of the host machine
3. continue to use Bamboo via localhost:8085
4. Run a Build plan with a JUnit parser task 
5. click on the "See detailed test results for [stage] 
6. wait while you are rerouted to a non- helpful URL
fields.summary: On local installations of Bamboo, if the IP address of the host machine changes, the detailed test results page (using JUnit parser) do not refer to localhost:, they refer to [Base URL] which has changed.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo Cloud shows "not valid: is this a git repository" system errors.
It occurs when Bamboo runs the command {{/usr/bin/git ls-remote}} to check the remote Bitbucket repositories.

{noformat}
com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandException: command /usr/bin/git ls-remote https://s********s:********@bitbucket.org/s********s/pjh-elect failed with code 128. Working directory was [.]., stderr:

h3. Environment
* Bamboo
* Bitbucket Cloud

h3. Steps to reproduce:
# Configure a "Bitbucket Cloud" repository under "Linked repositories"

*Result:*

fields.description:
*Problem Definition*
Some customers will isolate the Maven repository at a more granular level to prevent downstream plans picking up libraries installed by an earlier failed builds. (The m2 repository is set at the agent level, instead of the plan level.) Adding a -Dmaven.repo.local argument is possible but it has to be done for every task individually. 

*Suggested Improvement*

An good improvement for Bamboo would be a option for per-job or per-plan, which can be overridden in the Maven task would be preferred.

*Workaround*
One suggestion would be calling Maven via a wrapper and adding it there.
fields.summary: Support local repository in Maven task

fields.description:
Hi,

right now we are using an scp task to copy our built artifact to our servers and an ssh task to unpack and restart the processes on the servers. But for what we can see the tasks can only run in series.

Unfortunately for many servers this does not scale well. With a lot of traffic our servers need some time to finish the restarts because it has to wait for all connections to close. It would be much better to be able to let the tasks of the deployment run in parallel as an option. This way we could deploy in parrallel to all servers and the deployment time would not grow linearly to the number of target servers, but would only take as long as the slowest deployment.

I hope the feature request is understandable. If you have further questions do not hesitate to contact.

Thanks
Michael
fields.summary: Deploy to multiple machines in parallel

Currently Bamboo only loads 50 plans 
h3. Suggested Solution
* Provide the option to list all plans as a button
* Store loaded selection as cache to prevent the need of reloading if there are no changes
fields.summary: Option to show all plans in a single page on the Bamboo Dashboard

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Editing the source repository for a plan branch only allows you to choose from one branch option even if others exist. This is particularly challenging when that one option isn't the branch you're looking for.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a build and connect it with a repository containing branches
# Create a plan branch and save it
# Go to branch configuration
# Click source repository
# Tick 'Override the plan's default repository' if it isn't already
# Next to branch click the drop down.

h3. Expected Results

All branches will be shown

h3. Actual Results

Only one branch is shown (the current one)

h3.Workaround

After overriding the source repository:

# Click load repositories next to your repository and choose another one
# Change back to the original repository

Your branch drop down will now be populated with all branches.
fields.summary: When editing the source repository for plan branches only one branch option shows

fields.summary: Display project-wide graph for build dependencies

fields.description:
Hi Atlassian Team,

In some of our Bamboo plans we would like to send customized emails, for example when we deploy new version of application using Bamboo, we would like to inform business & testers via human understandable email.

We are aware of following feature:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/modifying-notification-templates-289276982.html
but this is not enough since we don't want to change global Bamboo notification for all emails, we also don't want to restart Bamboo server each time we modify email template.

We are also aware of linux commands like sendmail but our Bamboo Agents are not allowed to send mails, just Bamboo Master is configured to do so.

We suggest following:
- Bamboo should have Send Email task which should of course send email
- It should be possible to specify to, cc, subject, body, attachments, etc.
- It should be possible to define email body using template using Freemarker or similar technology
- In this template it should be possible to use placeholders like bamboo.buildKey which should be replaced by actual value
- It should be possible to load email template from Repository (GIT, SVN, etc) so that it could be defined on one place

Please notice that Jenkins (which is free) has similar component:
https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/Email-ext+plugin
so Bamboo (which is paid) should not be behind.

Many thanks,
Ondrej Lerch
fields.summary: Send customized email via Bamboo Task

fields.description:
We use Bamboo Cloud. I'd like to have certain variables for branch plans set by default when the branch plan is detected/created.

The particular use case revolves around Salesforce metadata. For a "master" branch build it should do a deploy to the Salesforce org. For a branch build it should just verify that the branch is deployable (and not actually do the deploy).

I have an adequate solution already as part of the ant job:

	<condition property="sfdc.checkonly" value="false" else="true">
	   <equals arg1="${bamboo.planRepository.branchName}" arg2="master"/>
	</condition>

This is OK but it creates a dependency on bamboo, and on the name of the master branch ("master").

It would be cleaner if I could just set "sfdc.checkonly" to true for Branch plans. My script will have fewer dependencies and be locally verifiable.

Variables are already editable in Branch plans, so I think this would fit with current features.
fields.summary: Default Branch Plan Variables

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When Bamboo is down for maintenance during a backup / export, calls to the Bamboo web server return an HTTP status code of *500* or *302* redirect to errorEvents.action, which is defined as "Internal Server Error: A generic error message, given when an unexpected condition was encountered and no more specific message is suitable." (from Wikipedia)
This may present issues for customers looking to monitor their applications by HTTP status code, as a *500* response could be indicative of a number of different issues and can't necessarily be considered a "working" response.

h3. Suggested Solution
Bamboo should instead return *503*, defined as "Service Unavailable: The server is currently unavailable (because it is overloaded or down for maintenance). Generally, this is a temporary state." This would provide a more specific and accurate HTTP response.

REST endpoints to return the server status such as {{rest/api/latest/server}}, should be exempt from the 302 redirect and return the server state as part of the response aka {{state:MAITENANCE}}

h3. Workaround
N/A
fields.summary: Return sensible HTTP status code such as "503" during backup instead of "500" or 302 redirect to errorEvents.action

fields.description: It would be nice to have the ability to set some required fields in Bamboo when manually triggering a build. For instance, force the user to enter a comment when a build is manually triggered. Something similar to what we have in JIRA. When a user tries to create a JIRA issue, it's possible to set the _Comment_ field as required in such a way that the user will not be able to create the issue until a comment is added. When a user clicks the {{Run > Run Plan}} button, Bamboo could display a pop-up so the user could add a comment to the build. At the same time, if the same Plan detects a change (which means it has a Trigger in place), it should automatically trigger the build without waiting/asking for any comments, the required field would take place when the build is manually triggered.
fields.summary: Required fields when triggering a build

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Google has introduced a tool called [Repo|https://code.google.com/p/git-repo/], which is built on top of git and allows multiple repositories to be wrapped into one location and treated as a single unit. Customers would like to make use of this to allow build plans to be linked to a Google Repo repository (a wrapped set of repositories), and therefore allow the existing functionality of change detection and branch detection to be triggered by any one of the repositories contained within a Google Repo wrapper

h3. Suggested Solution
Add Google Repo as a new linked repository type, to allow for all existing functionality around change detection and branch detection to be used by a Google Repo wrapped set of repositories

h3. Workaround
Customers would have to either specify a set of repositories manually within each build plan or define a custom Repo command to perform their checkouts - neither of these would allow users to take advantage of Bamboo's change & branch detection features
fields.summary: Add support for Google's Repo tool

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Customers want to prioritise one Job within a build plan so that it runs before other jobs, for instance because one job is known to have a longer running time and the overall build time depends on this job running first.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow for a priority to be set for jobs within a build plan that pushes specified jobs above other jobs from that plan in the build queue

h3. Workaround
Jobs for builds that have been submitted to the build queue can be individually reordered at runtime, however this must be performed manually and does not guarantee that a given job will be run first (e.g. another job might begin running)
fields.summary: Allow prioritisation of jobs within a build plan

fields.description:
In bamboo plugin development, I want to use the packages [com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.release|https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/5.9.7/com/atlassian/bamboo/plugins/jira/release/package-summary.html]. I want to get the JIRA version number when the build is triggered from a JIRA release.
However, there are a few problems / reasons why I can't use this package
1) the bamboo system bundle does not contain this package
2) the bamboo jira plugin itself does not export it's own packages (com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.*). It only exports com.atlassian.devstatus and com.atlassian.devstatus.build. 

When I include the package com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.release in my own plugin that I am developing, using the maven dependencies (working around the JDOM issue etc), it compiles great, but when it hits code that uses this class it fails, because it is using two different jar files/ classes for the same class names.

For example, when it hits this piece of code:
{code}
if (buildContext
    .getTriggerReason()
    .getKey()
    .equals("com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin.jira:jiraReleaseTriggerReason"))  {
   JIRAReleaseTriggerReason jiraTriggerReason = (JIRAReleaseTriggerReason) buildContext.getTriggerReason();
{code}
it throws this error when it hits the second statement:
{quote}
java.lang.ClassCastException: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.release.JIRAReleaseTriggerReason cannot be cast to com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.release.JIRAReleaseTriggerReason
{quote}

This was when I was debugging and I verified that the triggerReason in the buildContext was definitely a JIRAReleaseTriggerReason instance.

I believe this is because it's getting the new class definition from the com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.release package that I included with my plugin, while it's getting the instance of the class from the buildContext, which comes from the bamboo jira plugin itself.

As a result, I can't use these packages in my plugin at all. I can't even import the components (using component-import) published by the jira release plugin. E.g. If I want to import the component jiraReleaseTriggerReason, I can't use it, because the interface com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.release.JIRAReleaseTriggerReason is not available to import in my java code.

The solution is that Bamboo JIRA plugin should export the packages com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.* so they can be used in other plugins.
fields.summary: Bamboo JIRA plugin is not exporting it's own packages com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.jira.*

fields.description:
h3. Summary
 * Bamboo Variables not being properly checked before colon

h3. Environment
* Bamboo Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Access any Bamboo instance, and browse through to "Configure Plan"
# Create or Edit a 'Docker' Task
# In the Repository field, use a variable before a colon, like ${ variable }:${ variable }


h3. Expected Results
 * Fully accepted field configuration

h3. Actual Results
 * Displaying {color:red}"Invalid repository name (${variable}), only [a-z, A-Z, 0-9_.-] are allowed"{color}
 
h3. Notes
It looks like the Repository field is checking for the special characters before the Colon without considering that a variable may be used in that place. If the Repository field does not contain a colon, it will provide an error for the variable without performing the proper variable replacements first.

Bamboo should make sure to perform its validation of the URL _after_ the Variables have properly replaced the value before the colon.


h3.Workaround
No current workaround
fields.summary: Bamboo Variables not correctly checked before Colon
Documentation - Include ACL restrictions on S3 buckets

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently the Export capability of Bamboo does not export shared repository credentials, which means that after import this information needs to be added manually.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
The Export capability of Bamboo exports shared repository credentials along with all other data.

h3. Workaround

Manually add shared repository credentials after import of data
fields.summary: As an administrator I want to be able to export shared repository credentials so I can import them in a new instance

fields.description: My release build plan has deployments defined, few of which are triggered by release. Bamboo version 5.8.5 build 5875 shows the deployment as active/triggered only when it is actually running, deploying. It would be nice to show status somehow that the deployment build is triggered by release and queued up waiting for free agent to execute, so before it is actually running. Now, in this time in between triggering and actually running deployment, there is no notification for user that the deployment was successfully triggered and what actual status is. Because of this, on busy Bamboo installation, I suspected deployment trigger configuration and all sorts of other things, wasted time, while everything was actually OK.
fields.summary: Show scheduled/queued deployment build status

fields.summary: Bamboo charts are not rendered when truetype fonts are not installed in the OS
XCode plugin should be bundled with Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Using the Deploy to Tomcat task it takes about 20 minutes to fail the build when the Tomcat server isn't found or the wrong port is set (hence it times out).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a  job to use a Deploy to Tomcat task
# In the _Tomcat Manager URL_ field use an offline (or nonexistent) Tomcat server and/or a wrong port (on my tests I used http://192.168.10.10:10100/manager/)

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo quickly identifies the server is down/unresponsive/nonexistent and the task fails quickly.
h3. Actual Results
Bamboo takes around 20 minutes to fail the task with the following error:

If on my Bamboo set up I choose to have only one image and run only one plan at the time, 20 minutes of waiting is a very long time.
fields.summary: Deploy to Tomcat task takes too long to fail if the server times out

fields.description:
When I release a project through Jira I have the choice of choosing to kick off a new Bamboo build with the release. Part of this action is the option to "Override variable" for the build plan. The user enters the desired variables into the UI the first time and on subsequent attempts the values for these overrides persist in that UI.  

The bug is that on these subsequent attempts the override variables is are not actually passed to the Bamboo build plan. It ends up using the default instead.

The workaround is to make sure you delete and re-add the override variable when you retry a Jira release.
fields.summary: Bamboo variable override isn't passed along when a Jira Release is retried

fields.description:
Hi Bamboo Support Team:

We have created a bamboo plan where we are running pep8 tests and the tests run fine (we can replicate the same from our local machines and I've verified the junit xml reports are the same). However, the Bamboo JUnit Parser is unable to parse through the xml correctly and throws an error.

See the attached screenshots for the setup that we have for the JUnit Parser, the build results and logs from the build where it mentions that the tests ran.

-Cesar
fields.summary: Pep8 test results are not getting compiled correctly

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When creating a new branch or cloning an existing plan, a first-time build is performed. For some customers this is an unnecessary use of agent resources as no code changes have occurred, and a new build is not desired until a code commit is made.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add the ability to disable initial build on new branches/cloned plans, so first build only occurs on change detection.
fields.summary: Prevent first build on new branch/plan until change detection occurs

fields.description:
*Steps:*
1. setup GNU/Linux box without X11
2. install Bamboo on it
3. create application link between Jira and Bamboo
4. add Bamboo Plan Summary Chart gadget to Jira dashboard
5. error occurs

Asking for {{/bamboo/rest/api/latest/chart/planSummary.json}} returns HTTP 500 instead JSON.

*Solution:*
Add this line
{{CATALINA_OPTS="-Djava.awt.headless=true"}}
to file bin/catalina.sh or this line
{{System.setProperty("java.awt.headless", "true");}}
somewhere inside Bamboo source code (not sure - I'm not Java programmer).
fields.summary: "Bamboo Plan Summary Chart" gadget crash on machines without X11

fields.description:
There is an inconsistency in how Log's are rendered in bamboo.

In the "smaller" log viewer (the one that limits up to 100 lines) Control characters seem to render fine, however, in the larger log viewer all the control characters show up as junk (\n \n \n ESC etc).

It would be REALLY NICE if you could fix this. (see attached images)
fields.summary: LogViewer ANSI rendering inconsistency

fields.description: When HDD is out of space it crashes.
fields.summary: Crashes when out of space
